publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: As I strole the City, oft I 1viz: The Parliament House. See a Building large & lofty,
Not a Bow-shot from the Colledge,
Half the Globe from Sense & Knowledge,
By the Prudent Architect
Plac'd against the Church direct;
Making good my Grandams Jest,
“Near the Church──You know the rest.
Tell us what the Pile contains,
Many Heads that hold no Brains;
These Daemoniacs let me Dubb
With the name of Legion Club:
Such Assemblies you would swear
Meet, when Butchers beat a Bear:
Such a Noise & such Haranguing
When a Brother Thief is Hanging,
Such a Rout & such a Rabble
Run to hear Jack-pudding gabble,
Such a Crowd their Ordure throws
On a far less Villains Nose:
Could I from the Buildings top
Hear the ratling Thunder drop,
While the Devil upon the Roof
(If the Devil be Thunder proof)
Should with Poker fiery red,
Crack the Stones & melt the Lead,
Drive them down on every Scull
While the Den of Thieves is full
Quite destroy that Harpy's Nest,
How might then our Isle be blest?
For Divines allow that God
Sometimes makes the Devil his Rod.
And the Gospel will inform us
He can punish Crimes enormous:
Yet should Swift endow the Schools
For his 2“Lunaticks & Fools.────Alludes to a design D. Swift had of erecting & endowing a Mad-house. Lunaticks & Fools
With a Rood or two of Land
I allow the Pile may stand;
You perhaps may ask me, why so?
But it is with this Proviso;
Since the House is like to last,
Let a Royal Grant be past,
That the Club have leave to dwell
Each within his proper Cell,
With a passage left to creep in,
And a Hole above for Peeping;
Let them when they once get in
Sell the Nation for a Pin;
While they sit a picking straws
Let them rave at making Laws;
While they never hold their Tongue
Let them dabble in their Dung;
Let them form a grand Committee
How to Plague & starve the City;
Let them stare & storm & Frown
When they see a Clergy-Gown;
Let them e'er they crack a Louse
Call for th' Orders of the House;
Let them with their Gozling Quills
Scribble senseless Heads of Bills;
We may while they strain their Throats
Wipe our Arses with their Votes.

Let Sṛ3“Sṛ T viz: Sṛ Thomas Prendergast who this last Sessions of Parliament reflected in the House of Commons on the writings of Swift for abusing his Father, alluding to these Lines──_“`& so a purjur'd Dog denotes_“A Porter, Prendergast & Oats._Sṛ Thomas asserted that the Book deserved the Censure of the House; & some days afterwards acquainted them in an explanation of his former Oration that he would have punish'd the Author, if he could have done it by Law. and concluded with saying, that as the Satyr on his Father in those lines was not a breach of the Priviledge of Parliament he was for the present resolved to drop the Affair. Tom, that Rampant Ass,
Stuff his Guts with 4“Flax & Grass. alludes to Sṛ Thomas's pretending to be a great improver in Husbandry, in sowing of flax, reclaiming of Boys, &c. Flax & Grass,

But before the 5“The Priest he fleeces. The Committee, of which he was a Member, was then Sitting on a new Demand here of the Clergy for Agistmen & was passing severe Votes against it, tho' the Courts of Law had in many Cases lately determined that point in favour of the Clergy; but the Laity not being used to pay it, took this method of stopping the proceedings at Law till an Act of Parliament could be obtain'd to abolish that kind of Tythe. Priest he fleeces
Tear the Bible all to pieces;
At the Parsons, Tom, halloo──boy,
Worthy Offspring of a Shoe──boy.
Footman, Traytor, vile seducer,
Purjur'd Rebel, brib'd Accuser;
Lay thy paltry Priv'ledge aside,
From Papist sprung & Regicide,
Fall a working like a Mole,
Raise the Dirt about your Hole.
Come assist me Muse Obedient,
Let us try some new Expedient;
Shift the Scene for half an hour,
Time and Place are in thy Power;
Thither gentle Muse conduct me,
I shall ask & you instruct me:
See! the Muse unbars the Gate,
Hark the Monkeys how they prate!
All Ye Gods who rule the Soul
Styx (thro' Hell whose waters roll)
Let me be allow'd to tell
What I heard in yonder Cell!
Near the 6viz: The Door of the House of Commons. Door an Entrance gapes
Crouded round with Antick Shapes,
Poverty & Grief & Care,
Causeless Joy & true Despair,
Discord Perriwig'd with Snakes,
See the dreadfull strides she takes!
By this odious Crew beset,
I began to rage & fret,
And resolv'd to break their Pates,
E'er we enter'd at the Gates,
Had not Clio in the nick
Whisper'd me “Let down your stick,
What, said I, is this the Mad-house?
These, She answer'd, are but Shaddows,
Phantoms bodiless & Vain,
Empty Visions of the Brain,
In the Porch Briareus stands,
Shews a Bribe in all his Hands;
Briareus, the Secretary,
But we Mortals call him 7Cary. viz: Principal Secretary to the Lḍ Lieutenant. Cary;
When the Rogues their Country fleece
They may hope for pence apiece.
Clio, who had been so wise
To put on a Fools disguise,
To bespeak some approbation,
And be thought a near Relation,
When she saw two hundred Brutes
All involv'd in wild Disputes,
Roaring till their Lungs were spent,Priviledge of Parliament,
Now a new misfortune feels,
Dreading to be laid by the Heels;
Never durst a Muse before
Enter that Infernal Door;Clio, stifled with the Smell,
Into Spleen & Vapours fell,
By the Stygean steams that flew
From the dire infectious Crew;
Not the Stench of Lake Avernus
Could have more offended her nose;
Had she flown but o'er the Top
She must feel her Pinions drop,
And by Exhalations dire
Tho' a Goddess must expire:
In a fright she crept away,
Bravely I resolv'd to stay;
When I saw the Keeper frown,
Tipping him with half a Crown;
Now, said I, we are alone,
Name your Heroes, one by one:
Who is that Hell featur'd Brawler?
Is it Satan? No, 'tis Waller;
In what figure can a Bard dress
Jack the Grand Son of Sṛ Hardress,
Honest Keeper drive him further
In his looks are Hell & Murther,
See his Scowling Visage drop

Just as when he murther'd 8“Throp. viz: The Parson of Wallers Parish, who had so many Complaints against his Patron, that when collected together in writing they amounted to a small Volume, but before he had finish'd his disputes & Lawsuits Death put an end to his life by a Consumption. Throp:Keeper shew me where to fix

On the Puppy-pair of 9“Puppy pair of Dicks, viz: Dick Tigh & Dick Bettesworth, the former is Grandson of a Baker & a privy Councellor, the other amuses himself with instructing the Players, a great professor of Oratory & his Majesty's second Serjant at Law. Dicks,
By their Lanthorn Jaws & Leathern
You might swear they both were Brethern.
Dick Fits-baker, Dick the Player,
Old Aquaintance are you there?
Dear Companions hug & kiss,
Toast old Glorious in your Piss,
Tye them Keeper in a Tether,
Let them 10“Stare. Each of these Dicks has a peculiar undaunted aspect. Stare & Stink together,
Both are apt to be unruly
Lash them dayly, lash them duly
Tho' tis hopeless to reclaim 'em
Scorpion Rods perhaps may tame 'em.
Keeper Yon old Dotard Smoke,
Sweetly Snoaring in his Cloak;
Who is he? 'tis hum drum 11'humdrum Wynne. viz: Lieutenant General of his Majesty's Forces here. Old & infirm. Wynne,
Half encompass'd with his Kin;
There observe the Tribe of 12The tribe of Bingham. viz. a numerous family, many of which are Members of the House of Commons, famous for sitting and Voting together. Bingham,
For he never fails to bring 'em,

And the base Apostate 13“The base Apostate Vesey.──He was a remarkable Stickler for the Country Interest till this Lḍ Lieutenṭ made him Accomptant General & often repeated this expression in the House, “that his Heart bled at the distress of his Country; On his changing sides a Droll said that he never knew before the Duke of Dorset had any skill in Surgery, but now he was convinc'd his Grace had an Excellent Stiptick to heal Bleeding Hearts. Vesey
With Bishop Scraps grown fat & greasy;
While he sleeps the whole Debate,
They submissive round him wait,
Yet would gladly see the Hunks
In his grave & search his Trunks,
See they gently twitch his Coat
Just to Yawn & give his Vote
Allways firm in his 14“In his Vocation. These words & the foregoing lines allude to Wynne, not to Vesey. Vocation

For the Court against the Nation.Those are Allens, 15Jack & Bob.──·──·──────Son & Brother of the Lord Viscount Allen, whose Grandfather was a Stonecutter, & to perpetuate his fame, cut his name on a Chimney of the Lḍ Howths wcḥ is still extant. Jack & Bob,
First in every dirty Job,
Son & Brother to a queer
Brain-sick Brute they call a Peer;
We must give them better quarter
For their Ancestor trod Mortar,
And at Howth to boast his Fame
On a Chimney cut his Name:There sit 16“Dilks & Carter.────The first is a Capṇ of Foot, The second Capṇ of Dragoons, The third Master of the Rolls. Clements, Dilks & Carter
Who for Hell would dye a Martyr.
Such a Triplet could you tell
Where to find on this side Hell;
Gallows Carter, Dilks & Clements
Souse them in their own Excrements,
Every Mischief's in their Hearts
If they fail, his want of Parts.Bless us 17“Morgan. A Country Gentleman & Chairman to the Agistmen Committee. Morgan art thou there Man,
Bless mine Eyes art thou the Chairman,
Chairman to yon damn'd Committee,
Yet I look on thee with Pity;
Dreadfull sight, the learned Morgan,
Metamorphos'd to a Gorgan,
For thy horrid looks I own
Half convert me into Stone,
Hast thou been so long at School
Now to prove a Factious Fool?
Alma Mater was thy Mother;
Every Young Divine thy Brother,
Thou a disobedient Varlet
Treat thy Mother like a Harlot:
Thou ungratefull to thy Teachers,
Who are all grown Rev'rend Preachers;
Morgan, would it not surprise one?
Turn thy Nurishment to Poison;
When you walk among your Books,
They reproach you with their looks;
Bind them fast or from their Shelves
They'll come down & right themselves;
Homer, Plutarch, Virgil, Flaccus,
All in Arms prepare to backs us;
Soon repent, or put to slaughter
Every Greek & Roman Author;
Will you in your factious Phrase
Send the Clergy all to Graze,
And to make your project pass
Leave them not a blade Grass?
How I want thee, Hum'rous Hogart,
Thou I hear a pleasant Rogue Art,
Were but you & I acquainted
Every Monster should be painted,
You should try your Graving Tools
On this odious Groupe of Fools,
Draw the Beasts as I describe 'em,
Form their Features, while I gibe 'em,
Draw 'em like, for I assure you,
You will want no Charac'tura;
Draw 'em so that we may Trace
All the Soul in ev'ry Face.
Keeper I must now retire,
You have done what I desire,
But I feel my Spirits Spent
With the Noise, the Sight, the Scent,
Pray be patient, you shall find
Half the best are left behind.
You have hardly seen a score,
I can shew two Hundred more:Keeper, I have seen enough,
Taking then a pinch of Snuff,
I concluded looking round 'em,
May their God, the Devil, confound 'em.829-049P
